p: From another point of view, Zoubiri and Baaliouamer [ 154] documented the high effectiveness of EOs of T. minuta against mosquitoes of Anopheles gambiae, which are responsible for malaria transmission. The results were comparable to commercial, synthetic, insecticidal agents. What is more, T. minuta oil possesses phytotoxicity toward common weeds, including green amaranth ( Amaranthus viridis), vegetable amaranth ( A. tricolor), hairy beggars tick ( Bidens pilosa), little seed canary grass ( Phalaris minor), nettle leaf goosefoot ( Chenopodium murale), and barnyard grass ( Echinochloa crus-galli) [ 155]. Going further, Tagetes spp. are potential chromium hyperaccumulators. According to Coelho et al. [ 156], at Cr(III) concentrations up to 0.12 mmol/L, the plants accumulated levels above that proposed for hyperaccumulators while still maintaining considerable growth and even flourishing.
